title: 107_s1541
content: The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" can be cited as the short title. Federal-State agreements are addressed in the act. The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" allows states to enter agreements with the Secretary of Labor to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted all regular compensation rights and are not receiving compensation from any other source. The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" allows states to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted all regular compensation rights and are not receiving compensation from any other source. This includes individuals who have received all available regular compensation based on employment or wages during their base period, or whose rights to compensation have expired. The Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted all regular compensation rights. The weekly benefit amount is equal to the regular compensation payable under the State law for a week of total unemployment. The terms and conditions of the State law apply to claims for temporary emergency unemployment compensation, except where inconsistent with the provisions of the Act. The Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted their regular compensation rights. The maximum amount payable to any individual shall not exceed the amount established in their account. Governors can elect to trigger an extended compensation period to provide this assistance. The Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 establishes a temporary emergency unemployment compensation account for individuals who have exhausted their regular benefits. Governors have the option to trigger an extended compensation period for this assistance. The Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to establish temporary emergency unemployment compensation accounts for eligible individuals who have exhausted their regular benefits. The amount in the account is based on the individual's average weekly benefit amount for the benefit year, and may be reduced by any extended compensation received for the same benefit year. The Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970 determines an individual's weekly benefit amount based on the regular compensation payable for total unemployment under the State law. SEC. 4. Payments to states with agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation. Payments to states with agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation shall be equal to 100 percent of the compensation paid to individuals under the agreement. States will not receive payment for compensation already reimbursed under other federal laws. The amount payable to each state will be determined by the Secretary in advance or as reimbursement based on estimated entitlements for each calendar month. The Secretary will determine payments to states with agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation in advance or as reimbursement, based on estimated entitlements for each calendar month. Estimates may be adjusted for prior months' over or underpayments. SEC. 5. FINANCING PROVISIONS. Funds from the extended unemployment compensation account in the Unemployment Trust Fund are used to make payments to States with agreements under this title. The Secretary certifies payments to States, and the Treasury makes payments to States accordingly. Funds are appropriated to assist States in meeting administration costs of agreements under this title. Funds are appropriated to assist States in meeting administration costs of agreements under this title, without fiscal year limitation. Amounts are appropriated to the extended unemployment compensation account in the Unemployment Trust Fund for specific payments, without the need for repayment. SEC. 6. FRAUD AND OVERPAYMENTS. Individuals who knowingly make false statements or fail to disclose material facts to receive emergency unemployment compensation they are not entitled to will be ineligible for further benefits and may face prosecution under federal law. They will also be required to repay the improperly received funds to the state agency. Title 18, United States Code states that individuals who received emergency unemployment compensation they were not entitled to must repay the amounts to the State agency, unless the agency waives repayment if it was not the individual's fault and repayment would be unfair. The State agency can recover the repayment by deducting from future emergency unemployment compensation or other federal assistance. Individuals who received emergency unemployment compensation they were not entitled to must repay the amounts to the State agency. Repayment can be recovered by deducting from future emergency unemployment compensation or other federal assistance, with a maximum deduction of 50 percent of the weekly benefit amount. Repayment cannot be required until a fair hearing has been given and the determination has become final. Any determination by a State agency under this section is subject to review in the same manner as determinations under the State unemployment compensation law. Any determination by a State agency under this section shall be subject to review in the same manner as determinations under the State unemployment compensation law, and only in that manner and to that extent. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. This title defines key terms in accordance with the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. Agreements under this Act apply to specific weeks of unemployment. SEC. 9. TEMPORARY REDUCTION IN INTEREST RATE for repayments of advances to State unemployment funds. SEC. 9. TEMPORARY REDUCTION IN INTEREST RATE for State unemployment fund advances repayment. Interest rate reduced from 10% to 5% for advances made under the Social Security Act.
